It has happened a few times before, even recently as in 1992. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_United_States_presidential_elections_by_popular_vote_margin#Timeline I count ~6 times since 1900. Base rate of 6/30ish, so about 1/5 or 20%. Would take too much time to look up polls from these to see whether the >5% was well predicted by the polls or not. My guess is yes. So, we look for US polls and see if 3rd party is near or above 5%. Of the 3rd parties, Johnson is the only one close or above (Jill a few rare times). So we focus on him. Not all polls include him, annoying. I assume those that include all are most realistic. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nationwide_opinion_polling_for_the_United_States_presidential_election,_2016#Four-way_race So Johnson is polling at around 5%. Polls (or Wiki) round the numbers which is bad for us because 5.4% is very different to 4.6% for our model. Of the last 30 polls, 15 (50%) were >5%, 4 (13%) at 5% and 11 (37%) below. Given that the tendency is to be above, this means that the polls that round will tend to be on the >5% side, but the function is complicated I think. Perhaps weigh them as 15/(15+11), i.e. .57. This allows us to score the last 30 polls, which come out as 17.3/30. If we naively translate this to a proportion we get 58%. I'll take that.

 - Johnson's support is dropping fast - today he is at 5.2 percent in Real Clear Politics, from 5.8 percent two days ago.
 - Johnson's base rate is low: usually third-party candidates get even fewer votes than their last polls suggest (except Ross Perot in 1992);
 - Johnson's story was based on support from anti-Trump Republicans and independents disliking both candidates. The Rs are flocking back to Trump, it seems. Independents remain split, but in states where Clinton and Trump are close, the "useful vote" theory seems to prevail and they are abandoning Johnson.

I am adjusting my forecast. My reading of the polls is that they are still quite close. Trump is only about 1% below the margin of error and in some polls within the margin of error. In most places the total 3rd party (forecast) vote is more than the gap between Clinton and Trump. My understanding is that the 3rd party candidates are just attracting protest votes i,e. those who do not want to vote for either Clinton or Trump. The point of a protest vote is that you don't expect your candidate to win, you just want to show that you don't like the leading candidates.  The fairly high percentage of voters who tell the polls they support a 3rd party candidate shows the percentage of voters who don't want either Trump or Clinton as President. It does not indicate how much they dislike Trump or Clinton. I would suggest that most voters dislike one of the main candidates much more then they dislike the other main candidate. In the polling booth the voter faces a slightly different question to a poll, they have to decide if giving their vote to a 3rd party is likely to help one of the main party candidates become President, or if it will make no difference to who will be President. If they think it will make no difference then they will caste their protest vote for the 3rd Party. If they fear that by making a protest vote they risk allowing the worst main candidate become President they will vote for the least bad main candidate. My guess is that anywhere that poll data indicates that Trump and Clinton are within 4% of each other most of the votes for 3rd party candidates will be transferred to Trump and Clinton.

According to Real Clear Politics, in the three post-Trump-tape polls, Gary Johnson is averaging 7 percent with an average margin of error of 3 percent (http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/president/us/general_election_trump_vs_clinton_vs_johnson_vs_stein-5952.html) . This means that his poll-predicted result is in the 4-10 percent range. If his result is equally likely to be at any point in that range (what the statisticians call uniform distribution), the probability that he will get at least 5 percent is 5/6 or roughly 83 percent. However, I think the distribution of his chances is not uniform, but more like bell-shaped around 7 percent, albeit with fat tails. Why this may be so:
 - he is consistently polling above 5 percent (in fact, in the 6-8 percent range);
 - Nate Silver gives him about 6-6.3 percent (http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-election-forecast/?ex_cid=rrpromo#plus)
 - with Trump losing support, and doing his best to depress Clinton's support, chances are pretty good that this year the third-party vote would not decline in the last moment as it usually does. Moreover, the presidential elections is shaping not to be too close. This reduces the pull toward the candidates of the two largest parties  - people are less worried about "wasting" their vote on a third-party candidate and more likely to use such a vote to protest against the unpopular Trump and Clinton. On the basis of this, I am going to extremize my forecast - to 90/10.

The ‘Bleak’ History of Third-Party Presidential Bids Never in U.S. history has a third-party candidate been elected president. “History suggests that the prospects are in fact pretty bleak,” said Julia Azari, a political science professor at Milwaukee's Marquette University. “The idea of a centrist majority that actually votes is most likely a myth.” Since the election of Abraham Lincoln in 1860 established a Republican-Democrat duopoly, third-party candidates have competed in some two dozen presidential elections, and all suffered crushing defeats. Just nine of them topped 5 percent of the popular vote. The eight most recent third-party attempts—including Ralph Nader in 2000 and Ross Perot in 1996 and 1992—failed to win a single electoral vote.
http://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2016-01-27/the-bleak-history-of-third-party-presidential-bids In the 58 presidential elections since 1788, third party or independent candidates have won at least 5.0% of the vote or garnered electoral votes 12 times (21%); this does not count George Washington, who was elected as an independent in 1788–1789 and 1792, but who largerly supported Federalist policies and was supported by Federalists.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_third_party_performances_in_United_States_elections 12/58= 20.7% base rate for winning at least 5%.  However: Each election year, people have increasingly said they would consider an independent or third party candidate. But that support shrinks when they enter the voting booth: in 2012, 40% of people polled said they would consider voting for a third-party candidate, but only 1.8% actually voted that way in the election.
http://graphics.wsj.com/third-party-candidate-impact/ That 22x reduction in support suggests that no 3rd party candidate will cross the 5% threshold.  Washington Post-SurveyMonkey poll released this week shows Johnson with 13% support across all states, Stein is receiving 5% across all 50 states.
https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/politics/2016-election/50-state-poll/#results-table-container Neither Johnson or Stein will break 1% based on prior history.

Previously (2012) Gary Johnson got < 1%. For him to get 5% or more would require another 4% of voters to decide to vote for him. It seems fairly unlikely that many Democrats will suddenly become Libertarians, so it would require that around 8% of Republicans would decide that Libertarian was better than Trump. It seems possible that 1 Republican in 12 could think that almost anyone would be better than Trump, but these non_Trump republicans could not bother to vote at all, vote for Clinton (as the lesser of two evils), or vote for a 3rd party candidate. In some states it seems they could vote for Johnson or McMullin. Neither of them have any realistic chance of winning, so voting for either would count as a protest vote. If I supported a big political party that put up a candidate that I strongly did not like and I wished to register a protest vote, I would prefer to vote for a candidate that had views that seemed to me to match those that I would want my party to have. So a Republican making an anti-Trump protest is more likely to vote for McMullin than Johnson. But McMullin will not be on the ballot everywhere. So putting some numbers down: assume 50% of voters are generally Republican, but assume that many would not vote for Trump. Of those who would not vote for Trump assume that 20% don't vote for any candidate, 20% switch to Clinton, 30% vote for Johnson and 30% vote for McMullin. In order for Johnson to get 5% of the total vote he would need to 4% more of the votes than he got in 2012. This means 8% more of Republican votes, which if he is getting 30% of the Republican protest votes would mean that mean that the total anti-Trump vote by Republicans would need to be around 25% of the total Republican supporters.  For McMullin to get 5% of the total vote would mean picking up 10% of republican voter's support, to get that would require that the Anti-Trump protest by Republicans was around 27% of Republican supporters. Its possible for a political party to lose between 25% and 27% of its votes in one election but its pretty unusual.  But then we seem to be in very unusual times.

I think it's very likely - 90%? - that Trump will keep the R nomination. If he doesn't, I'd guess one chance in three he'd just quit, and two chances in three he'd run as an independent. I think if he runs, he's extremely likely - 96%? - to clear 5% of the popular vote. So let's say there's a 3% chance for the first option. For other 3rd party candidates: I presume (95%) that Gary Johnson will run, and presume further (95%) that he will suck, based on his 2012 performance (<1% of the vote). The protest vote in this scenario already has the Donald, so I don't see very favourable circumstances for the Libertarians to get votes. That would be a less than 1% chance for GJ getting 5%. I'm not aware of any other non-mainstream candidates likely to run at present, so let's leave that at 1%, which is rounding up.  The other possibilities would be (i) a Bernie insurgency (seems unlikely given his recent comments, but it's been that sort of year), or (ii) an alternative mainstream R candidate. For Bernie: it'd be a bridge-burning thing to actively stand, but he has very committed fans, and has some eccentricity to him. This is unlikely but not implausible. 4%? Maybe a little generous. I don't know. Tough year to call. For the Reps, I'm not aware of any credible R who's likely to stand, but - you know - Trump. I don't think there'd be much problem for an Alt-R candidate hitting 5% of the vote if they stood, but everyone seems prepared to hold their nose and wait four years for more favourable circumstances. 10%? The likelihood of this could increase if the polls got much worse. Which could well happen. Though it'd be intended to help congressional elections, rather than to win the WH. Let's go 10%. So 10+4+1 = 15%. [EDIT: It occurs to me that both DT and HRC have high unfavourability ratings. This could result either in a lower turnout, or in more votes going to third-party candidates. I still don't think the Libertarian ticket is going to be particularly appealing, but I think I should nudge up their chances by a couple of percent to reflect the greater number of potentially winnable voters. I'll up that from 1% to 3%, so I'd estimate there's a 17% chance of a non-DT third party hitting 5%.]

Historically, just 9 of 24 third party candidates in US election history have won more than 5% of the popular vote.  That's about a 37.5% success rate. Given the abnormal popularity of Bernie Sanders amongst young generations, and the corresponding higher turnout of this portion of the population, we may see him capture a decent portion of the popular vote.  However, he is likely to reluctantly throw his support behind Hillary Clinton, which will sharply lower his chances of capturing his own votes in the election.  I am assuming a large-scale regression to the mean, leaving about a 40% chance that he will capture more than 5% of the popular vote.  This leaves a 47% chance that no independent candidate will take home more than 5% of the vote.  A much lower chance than in past elections , but a realistic bet.

Since 1832, there have been 13 US presidential elections where a third party candidate got >5% of the vote, but since 1900 it's only 7 out of 29 - and one of those was a former president (Teddy Roosevelt in 1912) [1]. Post-WW2, it's 4 out of 17 presidential elections. Tentatively I set a base rate at about 25%. Switching to the inside view,  the two potential third party candidates to cross this threshold are a) Libertarian Party (presumably Gary Johnson) or b) someone else anointed by conservative elites. The Libertarian Party has been putting up presidential candidates for quite some time, and twice they have hit c.1% (1980 and and 2012) [1]. I don't see a strong reason to move from the base rate on the basis of the Libertarian Party. As for b), there are tremendous obstacles to this including ballot access, co-ordination problems, and finding someone with enough name recognition to make it worthwhile. As far as I am aware, it would be unprecedented in US presidential history. But it's not impossible, so I'm putting in a +5% modifier for this, which brings me to 30%.    [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_third_party_performances_in_United_States_elections#1996

So I looked at the history of the US elections, 1824 onwards. I could not find popular vote breakup data prior to this. There are 13 instances during these 48 elections, when at least a third (if not also a fourth, as in 3 cases) candidate got more than 5% votes. Also there is one election, where one candidate scored 4.93% - don't know what to do with this marginal data point, but for the sake of calculation, I will round up my probability upwards to nearest percent rather than down to incorporate this. Now the question is two way. One, will there be a third or fourth candidate etc? Two, will this candidate or these candidates poll more than 5% of popular votes (not electoral votes).  One is the primal / conditional point on which the second part depends upon. So to start with, the question is, is there a third candidate? Sanders? Another someone? I don't know yet - but given that there is a huge fracture in the Republican side at this moment, plus Sanders isn't giving up even now, this maybe a very fair outcome eventually. Of course, can never rule out an entirely third party or independent candidate. So, let me assign a favourable probability of 3/4ths that there will be a third candidate anyway! P.S 36 out of total 57 elections have actually seen a third or more candidates, which comes to about 64% times. I am only bumping it to 75%, as I think there is a higher likelihood of another candidate given deep fractures this time. Second, will this so called third candidate poll more than 5%? History says 13 out of 48 times, or 27%. I will dock it up a notch as once there was a marginal candidate, as mentioned earlier. So, 28%. Hence, my answer to start off comes to, 75% * 28% = 21%.

The most important input to my forecasts in the monkey cage challenge has been Trump's chances of getting 1237+ delegates. However, analysing my changes in forecasts so far two things have gone wrong:
	- I have been nowcasting rather than forecasting, ie overreacting to first Colorado and then New York
	- I just assumed 1237 was the hurdle. Taking the first error, I have now looked at every forthcoming primary (mainly based on the tools provided by 538 - http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/election-2016/can-you-get-trump-to-1237/), and ended up consequently focusing solely on the races in Indiana and California, there aren't too many margin of error in the others. On the second error, I am making the new assumption that 1195 is better hurdle, as it should be possible for Trump to convince 43 of the unbound delegates (Pennsylvania could provide at least 20) to vote for him. I wouldn't argue if anyone said it was lower but I figured 1180-1210 is the right range. Here is the possibility matrix as I see it:
Does Trump win the GOP nomination? 24% yes - see my other predictions for rationale Does Hillary win the Dem nomination 100% yes - see 538's take but Bernie making up the lost ground is now exceedingly unlikely < 0.5% If Trump loses, what are the chances he runs as a third party? I will generously say 4%. Mounting a 3rd party campaign is very, very expensive (http://www.vox.com/2016/3/18/11261778/donald-trump-third-party) and Trump has shown no inclination to spend much on his campaign so far, and his ground-game and regional infrastructure sucks. But there is still some chance of a limited third party run.  If he runs, what are the chances he gets 5%? I think this is nearly zero. Getting on the ballot is a huge task in most states, and by the time Trump knows if he's lost the GOP nomination - which will be on June 7 with CA, some of the deadlines have already passed. Even if Trump decided to pursue ballot access he would likely prioritize only a subset of states, reducing the pool of voters that can vote for him. Even existing parties that get on the ballot each year like the constitution party and the reform party only get on the ballot in 15 and 2-5 states respectively. So I think I round this down to 0%, but even a 10% chance, multiplied by the 4% chance of running, rounds down to 0%.  Does one of the other independents - Gary Johnson or Jill Stein - get to 5%? This one has a low base rate - it is relatively unprecedented in modern electoral politics - the most recent example is Ross Perot, who got 19% in 1992 (Ralph Nader in 2000 only got to 3.5%). There are also quite a few parallels there, in the anti-establishment bent of the election. I think a base rate of around 12% is reasonable - that is once every 9 or so elections, or every 35 years. Last election Jill Stein got 0.5%, and Gary Johnson 1.2%, that's also a useful anchor. But this is an unusual election, and both Donald and Hillary are very unpopular. A recent Monmouth poll showed Gary Johnson with 11% support in a poll against Trump and Clinton. I think if Trump wins the nomination, he has a fair chance of getting 5% - say 40% chance. I think the odds are a bit lower with a Cruz nomination (which I put at 64% chance), perhaps only 20%. I will keep monitoring polls and see. Apparently a lot of the support was coming from democrats turned off by Clinton (according to Monmouth), so perhaps we'll see a lot of Bernie voters voting for Johnson and the GOP nominee won't matter so much. So fo now I'll assume 20% chance if GOP nomniee is Kasich or some other random. That makes for .24 *.4 + .76 +.2 = 25% chance. Given the unusual nature of this year's election, a probability twice my assumed base rate seems totally comfortable, and if anything it might be higher. My numbers for probability of getting 5% given certain nominees (20%, 40%) will go up if I see more national polls with Johnson above 5%. I think Jill Stein's chances of getting > 5% are negligible.

This is less a question about the personality quirks of current candidates than it is a question of voter dissatisfaction. And there will be a lot of dissatisfied primary voters after the Republican and Democratic conventions, particularly if the eventual nominees are named Clinton and Cruz. Supporters of the insurgencies mounted by Sanders and Trump have already indicated that they are lightly, if at all, bound to major parties. Some will stay with the ticket because the major alternative is too ghastly to be risked. Others will go to the sidelines. But, having been energized by the possibility of "making a difference," the rest will look down the ballot. Threatening them with a "wasted vote" (circa 1992 and 2000) won't bring them back into the fold, as the establishment has been deemed corrupt from the beginning. The Libertarians have already qualified to be down-ballot in all 50 states. Given the foul mood of the electorate, 2016 will almost certainly be a banner year for them. But not so much for Mr. Trump, should he fail to capture the Republican nomination. The kind of organization required to get on the ballot nationwide, starting in July, is beyond his reach. Instead, he'd need to co-opt a preexisting organization, preferably one in search of a headliner. Pigs with wings are more likely to exist.

For this question, I started with the outside view. I used the post-WWII period, since this is the time period most relevant to the current system of political parties in the US (despite the switch of conservatives from the Democrats to Republicans). There have been 17 US presidential elections since WWII, and in 4 of these (1968, 1980, 1992, and 1996) a third-party candidate won more than 5% of the popular vote. This gives a base rate of 23.5% for a third party candidate winning more than 5% of the popular vote. However, we need to adjust this based on the special circumstances surrounding this election, especially with the chance of Donald Trump running as a third party candidate. Currently, prediction markets put the chances of a brokered convention at 63%. Analysis of the delegates at stake by the site fivethirtyeight has shown that Trump is unlikely to win the Republican nomination in the case of a brokered convention.  Now, in the case of a brokered convention, what is the chance of Trump running as a third party candidate? Predictit puts the chance of Trump running as a third-party candidate overall at 28%. However, this includes the probability that Trump will win outright without a brokered convention, so the conditional probability of Trump running, given a brokered convention is 28/63=44%.  If Trump runs as a third-party candidate, he is very likely to receive more than 5% of the vote- an analysis of candidates who left mainstream parties to run as third-party candidates by fivethirtyeight shows that the greatest decrease in polling numbers caused by this shift was a reduction by 2/3 of the overall vote share. Given that Trump is polling much higher than 15% in national polls, there is a very low chance that a shift to a third party run would give Trump less than 5% of the votes. The 28% chance of Trump running as a third-party candidate is averaged with the base rate of 23.5% for any candidate winning more than 5% to get 25.75 ~26%.  What about other candidates? Ben Carson currently has a 3% chance of a third-party run on PredictIt. Another chance is that, in the case of a Trump nomination, one of the Republican establishment (not Ben Carson) decides to mount a 3rd-party run to stop Trump. There might be a 10% chance of this occurring, given a Trump nomination (43% chance on predictit). 0.1*0.43=0.04, or a 4% chance someone other than Ben Carson mounts a 3rd-party run. Bernie Sanders may also run should he lose to Hillary Clinton, but the chance of this is very low (1%). Donald Trump as a Third-Party Candidate=26%
Chance of Ben Carson, another Republican, or Bernie Sanders=3% + 4% +1% = 8%
All other probabilities: 100%-34% = 66% Sources:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_third_party_performances_in_United_States_elections#Presidential
http://fivethirtyeight.com/features/its-probably-first-ballot-or-bust-for-donald-trump-at-the-gop-convention/
http://fivethirtyeight.com/datalab/trump-would-lose-badly-in-a-third-party-bid-but-he-could-take-the-republican-down-too/
https://www.predictit.org/Browse/Group/67/National

In the last 25 U.S. presidential elections, third-party candidates have topped 5% of the popular vote a total of six times. If we reduce our scope to the last 10 U.S. presidential elections, the 5% bar was cleared three times; it seems fair to say that there's a 24-30% chance of a third-party candidate with at least that much support in a generic election. 
This, however, is not a generic election. 
The scenarios I consider reasonably plausible include:
- Trump winning the GOP nomination, and Republicans turning to a third-party alternative (Rick Perry is commonly mentioned)
- Trump winning the GOP nomination, and Republicans uniting behind him
- Trump losing the GOP nomination and running as a third-party candidate
- Trump losing the GOP nomination and endorsing the party's nominee
We might also envision a third-party challenge rising out of a Sanders victory on the Democrat side, but my projections in that race have Clinton winning the nomination with a high degree of certainty, so I'm not going to bother with that.  I currently have Trump with a 54% shot at winning the nomination. There would be considerable pressure to find a third-party candidate in this scenario, due to fears of down-ballot effects if the candidates on offer are Clinton and Trump, but it's far less obvious who that candidate would be; I'm skeptical that Perry (for example) would be a convincing enough candidate to drive up voter turnout on the right. There's also the difficulty of timelines; there is a case to be made for running a right-wing third-party candidate even without a true chance at winning the election but with Trump looking beatable at a convention there's less motivation to act immediately and failing to act immediately will hobble a campaign (the timelines are brutal: http://static.politico.com/4b/2e/f597073c4ba18c25c6b1bc1396a4/independent-ballot-access.pdf).  I'm guessing here; but I'd say 5:1 that the party unites behind Trump or picks a third-party option too late to reach the 5% bar. That puts 9% in the "someone else" camp and 45% in the "no" box. It seems far more likely to me that Trump would run as a third-party candidate if he fails to secure the nomination. He's created more than enough wiggle room to get out of his loyalty pledge to the party if he fails to secure the nomination and the same factors which prompted a presidential run in the first place would suggest continuing it via a third-party route. I also see little reason to believe that he would hold back in the name of giving the Republican candidate a better chance at winning; Trump has made it clear with both public statements and donation history that he has little interest in putting party goals ahead of personal goals.  That leaves timelines as the key problem for Trump, since he already has an organization, funding and a national profile. Because it's unlikely that his situation will be resolved prior to the GOP convention in mid-July, which will make it too late for 12 states (the 11 above + Missouri) and make it extremely difficult in a number of others. Would he run purely as a protest candidate with no chance of winning?  Again, I'm guessing; I'd call it 3:1 that he doesn't run on a third-party ticket in the event that he fails to secure the GOP nod. That adds 12% to the "Trump" box and 34% to the "No" box. The timelines are just too tight; he's basically committed at this point to attaining the presidency via a place on the Republican ticket.
